281.heading: Amar Singh.
281.title: Dictionnaire EncyclopÃ©dique de HÃ©ros et Auteurs de BD
281.author: Henri Filippini

282.title: "Amar Singh Rathor : Of Rajput Pride and Honour"
282.author: script, Kamlesh Pandey ; illustrations, Pratap Mulick ; editor, Anant Pai
282.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 681 (1978, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Amar Singh Rathor was a commander in the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan's army. The emperor held him in great esteem and valued his service. But once when Shah Jahan was tricked into imposing a heavy fine on the Rajput by jealous and scheming courtiers, Amar Singh was furious and defiant. In the ensuing battle for honour, the Rajput fought bravely and escaped but was killed by his treacherous brother-in-law. His body was, however, retrieved from the emperor's custody by two comrades and cremated with due respect."

292.heading: Amaravati.
292.title: "Indra and Shachi : the Lord of Heaven and His Devoted Wife"
292.author: retold by Lakshmi Seshadri ; artwork, M
292.appears_in: N. Nangare. 31 p. in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 567 (1974, 1998 printing).
notes: Begins: "Indra was the king of the Devas. He lived with his queen, Shachi in his celestial city, Amaravati."

Summary from back cover: "Even gods can be prey to their inner torments. Lying and killing for the sake of peace and order, Indra felt he was unworthy of being king of heaven. A new king was installed on his throne! Now it was up to Indra's wife Shachi to ensure that his honour survived. Would the gods ever regain their respect for her beloved?"
Subtitle, series and summary from 2010 printing.

contents.author: illustrated by Michael Zulli and Dick Giordano
contents.title: Hob's leviathan

contents.author: illustrated by Shea Anton Pensa and Vince Locke
contents.title: Cerements

contents.author: illustrated by Bryan Talbot, Mark Buckingham, Dick Giordano, Steve Leialoha, Gary Amaro and Tony Harris.
contents.title: World's end

notes: "Originally published in single magazine form as The Sandman 51-56"
Summary (from OCLC): Stephen King's Introduction sets the stage for a series of tales with a haunting geometry

some angular, some parallel, some concentric. An eerie mirror of Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, this collection tells of a group of travelers from throughout time, myth and dream, who converge at a mysterious inn to seek refuge from a "reality storm". Mature readers.

334.title: "Amateur Detective"
334.author: [No author]
334.series: Father O'Malley) 6 p. in Catholic Comics, v. 1, no. 11
notes: Summary: The elderly Trent sisters live alone, with their brother, whom they think is rich. He locks himself in his room and dies, and the sisters call a passing boy to break in. When the sisters find no money they tie the boy up and accuse him of theft. The boy gets loose long enough to call Father O'Malley, who is met at the door by a Trent sister with a gun. O'Malley breaks into the house another way and finds the brother's will, in which he reveals that he had no money.

notes: Gildersleeve (1908-1966) drew cartoons almost exclusively about amateur radio for the magazine QST; with a photograph of Gildersleeve and 2+ pages of sample cartoons.

367.title: Amar Chitra Katha
notes:
Illustrated classics from India. See also the features and sources
  • Hitopadesha
  • Jataka Tales
  • Panchatantra
Later printings have divided the issues into five subseries:
  • Bravehearts : "Stirring tales of brave men and women of India."
  • Epics and Mythology : "Best known stories from the Epics and the Puranas."
  • Fables and Humour : "Evergreen folktales, legends and tales of wisdom and humour."
  • Indian Classics : "Enchanting tales from Indian literature."
  • Visionaries : "Inspiring tales of thinkers, social reformers and nation builders."
